>>837cbd4f-c8bc-4da2-b2df-510f43cd1e72
>and it apparently gives board owners the kind of moderating powers they'd have on a normal website
The kind YOU have on the whole of 08chan, retard. Remember when you nuked the whole of 08chan by switching to ZeroID? Well, you could craft a change in the content.json to remove any post you want just like you did that time. In a merger system, **I assume** you wouldn't have that power over the whole zite, each board owner would have power over their own board, and you would just have the power to remove them from the boards list. In any case, the merger sites system is supported **(or is it a custom feature not available in the one from gitgud?)** but not enforced by Millchan engine.

>>da307d1b-f147-4160-9b42-ba7b4324dff6
Yeah, either Millchan's or ZeroFrame code are absolute dogshit. Something locks the UI thread for tens of seconds at a time when it needs to process something. Plus they're all absolute memory hogs. I'm talking 15 GB with a couple tabs open. Are you using the default site or are you using the Millchan update hack?
https://anonfile.com/Kc07Bf2bnf/update_08chan_s_Millchan_version_201908081621_zip

Switch to the updated version of Millchan engine.
Stop parroting that it's slow as fuck and try it for yourself. It's not '''that''' much slower than the default.
https://anonfile.com/Kc07Bf2bnf/update_08chan_s_Millchan_version_201908081621_zip
At some point it would be beneficial to establish a working relationship with them and keep the two sites more or less in sync, so we can benefit from their improvements and vice versa.
A hard fork of an old version has no future. They are the ones who developed it, they are the ones who know how the code works. Hacking a compiled half-minified js file of an unknown version of a typescript project is an uphill battle.

>>f2279808-bf70-4181-9728-11bb5e49dceb

>>a1ca60c9-1c81-478e-812f-11f145e2bbc5

posts.subject: SHTF / Preparedness thread
posts.body:
== SHTF / Preparedness thread ==
I'll begin. As generators draw too much attention in a SHTF scenario, do you think solar panels will be useful? How likely is it that somebody will see them above your roof and suspect you'll be a good robbery victim?
What about ham radio? Is it any good or is a short wave receiver to get news and chink handhelds for tactical comms enough?
What do you think is the most useful trade to learn now to make a living when the grid goes down?
For folks who live in the city, bugging in or bugging out? Bugging in sounds cheaper because you don't need a secondary property, plus you can keep all the equipment you already have (tools etc).
In any case I'm positive the bug out location should be made of concrete so it can be effectively defended without it getting burned down by packs of roaming niggers.
